answers.answer: Number 1: Cut out the desserts! What is the point in taking medications and then eating sugar? Kind of counterproductive. I know it's hard to do but it will be worth it.Unfortunately, diabetes is a progressive disease. It's often necessary to change medications as one stops working. Also, over time it may be necessary to go on insulin as your body stops producing it. This happens an average of 10 years after diagnosis. But what you don't say is what you do about diet and exercise. You can do a lot to help whatever medications you take by getting regular exercise and by eating less carbs; that would include ctting out all desserts and reducing things such as bread, potatoes, pasts, etc.

question: I have a pituitary tumor, hashimotos and type 2 diabetes.  My A1c is 5.5 at most recent testing and my highs up until recently have never gone above 180.   However, I started having really bad lows frequently so my dr. said I could stop taking my Janumet.  Recently she suggested going back to Metformin for weight loss and PCOS possibility.  I have stuggled with the Metformin gas, stomach cramps and loose stools.  However, I really want to make it work because lately I have been having high blood sugars.  Tonight I got up to 300 for the first time ever. (when testing anyhow).  I have been drinking gobs of water and retesting and it is coming back down, still at 220 right now.Any suggestions?  (PS.. yes I did eat dessert tonight... and that is the cause of the high).When I was pregnant 8 years ago and had gestational diabetes, I had no problem controlling my blood sugars and always staying below 120, but I am really struggling with it now.
title: concerned about levels
